Hold a commemorative luncheon for five Turkish veterans visiting Adelaide for the 90th commemoration of the Gallipoli landings.
To establish a War Memorial Web-site. The web-site will contain photographic and textual data of all war memorials in SA.
Restore the Memorial Gates at the Pinnaroo Soldiers Memorial Hospital.
Install a plaque dedicated to 2/1 Aust Mech Eqpt Coy RAE and 2/3 Aust Railway Const (ME) Coy RAE at the Rocky Creek War Memorial Park.
Restore photographs of 45 WWI soldiers from the Scottsdale area including one of Alfred Gaby VC who was born and educated at Scottsdale.

Produce a flyer to promote and educate schools and the wider community about the Sandakan to Ranau death march and attract greater participation in 60th anniversary commemoration of this event on 29 May 2005.
To restore the local community war memorial.
To restore WWII Memorial Gates and posts.
Repair and upgrade the steps leading to the Burnie War Memorial.
To erect an Anzac Commemorative plaque and a sandstone plinth. This will be dedicated to 90th Anniversary of the landings at Gallipoli.
Restore the ‘For God and Country Memorial’ plaque located at Anzac Square, Brisbane.
Refurbish and upgrade Canowindra Memorial Park by removing dilapidated paths and walkways and adding signage at entrance with Army, Navy, Air force and nurses stencilled emblems on pathway.
Make enhancements to the existing Aboriginal Memorial on Mount Ainslie, including upgraded access.
Construct three display cabinets to store wartime memorabilia to be displayed at the Armadale RSL Sub-Branch.
Purchase two display cabinets to display wartime memorabilia at the Armadale RSL Sub-branch.
Construct a mobile cenotaph that can be transported to rural schools in the district, which do not have a memorial, to enable the schools to conduct commemorative services.
To create a commemorations area for residents of Wahroonga Friendship Village facility for Anzac and Remembrance Days activities.

Extend and enhance the existing war memorial area in Anzac Park to incorporate the cenotaph. Funds are sought for the polished block walls, which will be dedicated to all conflicts, incorporating the three service badges.

Replace the existing war memorial wall at Lyle Rose Park, Sawtell. The memorial wall is severely cracked and deteriorated. The existing 384 commemorative plaques have been carefully removed and cleaned and they will be replaced on the new wall.
Refurbish the ‘Fallen Soldiers War Memorial’ in Subiaco.
Refurbish the Cannonvale Cenotaph by adding a new plaque to recognise all wars and conflicts and adding the three services badges.

Funding for the GST component for grant G160430 approved in May 00. When this application was submitted, GST component was left off. Sub-branch has only a handful of members, all in their 80s, and are unable to raise the remainder of the funds.
To supply webbing flag holders for 46 schools (2 each). This project will involve students statewide in Anzac Day marches with them able to parade 46 banners from Tasmanian units.
Install security cameras at the Hobart VC Memorial to prevent vandalism.
To hold BBQs in Tasmania as part of 60th Anniversary celebrations of the cessation of WWII hostilities. The BBQs are planned for venues in the north, northwest, south and east of the state.
To construct a War Memorial in Upper Coomera.
Construct a new community war memorial at Runaway Bay.
Hold a VP Day commemoration and celebration at Cooroy.

To refurbish and repair the Tumut Community War Memorial in Richmond Park, Tumut. Carry out repairs to base structure, polish top section showing insignia of RSL, AIF and Australian coat of arms, refurbish and refit existing bronze plaques.
Purchase two display cabinets to house wartime memorabilia at the Caloundra RSL Club rooms.
Community commemorations to celebrate the 60th Anniversary of VP Day.

Undertake a major restoration and upgrade of the local cenotaph that includes moving the memorial, restoring and adding a number of new plaques. As well it will include new paving, fencing, garden beds and flagpoles.
Construct a mobile display cabinet for Beaudesert RSL Sub-branch to house memorabilia, which will be transported to schools, libraries and community centres.
To purchase a replacement plaque for the Capel RSL Sub Branch War Memorial.
Hold a commemoration of the 40th anniversary of the arrival of Australian combat troops in Vietnam. 250 attendees.
Upgrade of the Augusta War Memorial with paving and new sandstone blocks and plaque brackets.

To update existing war memorial at Shoalhaven Heads with the addition of two commemorative plaques, refurbish a 25-pound WWII gun and winged propeller which will be mounted alongside the existing anchor at the memorial.
Repair and restore the St Georges Basin War Memorial located at Lions Park, St Georges Basin.
Repair a damaged WW1 plaque on the Yarram Memorial Gates pillar and mount a new plaque on the other pillar to honour those from the area who served in WWII and later conflicts.
Install an honour board at the Port Lincoln RSL Sub-branch to commemorate ex servicewomen who enlisted from the area.

Combined research project between Tumby Bay SA RSL and Tumby Bay Area School, to interview surviving veterans in the area, and scan and record all memorabilia for display in school web-site and for use in Centenary celebrations.
To restore Trophy Gun No. 547 WWI German/Turkish 7mm Krupp Field Gun.
Construct a Vietnam War Memorial in Mothers’ Memorial Gardens, Toowoomba.

To restore 41 deteriorated commemorative plaques and add a further five plaques to the Memorial Wall in the Remembrance Garden at Merriwa. These plaques are dedicated to the deceased veterans of the Merriwa RSL Sub-Branch.
Refurbish two World War I Honour Boards. They will be housed in the Gosnells Civic Centre after refurbishment.
Hold the first national reunion of the
To purchase three secure illuminated war memorabilia display units for their Boer War to the Vietnam War memorabilia collection.
To finalise Post WWII Honour Roll at Rosedale Memorial Hall.
Erect plaques to Boer War, WW1, WW2, Korea, Borneo, Indonesia and Vietnam conflicts, which will contain data on numbers who served in each service casualties and dates of conflicts.
Restore commemorative plaques on Sawyers Gully WW1 Memorial Gates.
To produce two honour boards to commemorate WW1 and WWII veterans from the Nagambie area.
Restore the Oxley War Memorial which has been neglected for some years.
Restore the Heidelberg WW1 Cenotaph and upgrade the area including building WWII and post WWII memorial stone plaques.
Preserve wartime memorabilia located at the Northampton RSL Sub-Branch.
Restore and upgrade the Babinda Cenotaph by repairing and repainting the ships fittings, relocating gun and restoring an honour roll.
Restore the Cockatoo RSL WW1 War Memorial.
Purchase two display cabinets to exhibit wartime memorabilia at the Banyo RSL Club.
Erect a plaque at the Darwin Cenotaph dedicated to all those who served from 1942 to 1974 in Airfield Construction Squadrons, and in war zones both in Australia and overseas.
Restore the Beaconsfield Cenotaph in Tasmania. Work to include sealing the stone and renewing the lettering in gold enamel.

An original wrought iron fence that surrounded the Midlands Cenotaph was recently discovered after being stored away in 1958. A plaque will be made for the fence in memory of those who enlisted from the Midlands area.
Place a bronze plaque onto the existing New Norfolk War Memorial. The plaque will list names of servicemen from the Derwent Valley who were killed while on active service during WWII.
To preserve local wartime memorabilia photos by framing and displaying in the local RSL.
To restore the Ross World War II Honour Roll by regilding the lettering which has faded.
Paint a mural on the blank wall behind the St Helen’s Cenotaph. The mural will depict Australia’s military heritage.
Renovate and restore Birchip, Curvo and Watchem War Memorials.
Plant an Avenue of Honour to be dedicated to veterans who served during WWI and WWII. Plaques to be set at the base of the trees.
Erect two plaques on the Tara Light Horse Memorial dedicated to servicemen and women who served in all wars and conflicts and a plaque dedicated to Light Horsemen from the district.
Erect three honour boards in the foyer of the Blackwood & Districts Memorial Hall dedicated to WWI, WWII, Korea, Malaya, Vietnam and Peacekeeping Forces.
Restore, preserve and display 11 WWI and WWII photographs of veterans who made the supreme sacrifice from the Echunga district.
Install a WWII Honour Board to be located at the Victor Harbour RSL Club rooms, and erect a plaque dedicated to all wars and conflicts at the Soldiers Memorial Gardens.
To restore and repair the community war memorial.
Upgrade the wartime memorabilia display housed at Southport RSL.

Involve 19 schools in the Sunnybank Hills district and two cadet units affiliated with the sub-branch to develop and implement a program based around the theme of celebration, commemoration and service.
Build an Avenue of Honour to commemorate those members of the Armoured Corp who were killed in service in Vietnam.

Hold a 60th anniversary commemorative service to mark the last Sandakan death march on 29 May 2005 at the Sandakan Memorial in Anzac Park, Tamworth. A re-dedication of the memorial will also take place.
Construct display cases to exhibit wartime memorabilia and restore and display memorabilia at the RSL Club rooms.
To purchase two lockable and safety glassed display cabinets to display donated wartime memorabilia at the Lambton-New Lambton RSL Sub-Branch.
Redevelop the existing war memorial site at Lancelin.
Commemorate the 60th anniversary of the end of WWII and the 90th anniversary of Gallipoli and hold a veterans reunion luncheon.

Provide lighting to the Cenotaph at Warren. This lighting will ensure safety and visibility for the ex-service members attending commemorative services. It will also contribute to the security and enhance the appearance of the Cenotaph.
Dedicate memorial plaques and hold a Lone Pine Tree planting ceremony to commemorate the 90th anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli at Gresford Cenotaph.

For the Hunter Valley District RSL Sub-branches to dedicate a commemorate plaque for the 90th anniversary of the Landing of Gallipoli, at Simpson Park War Memorial, Muswellbrook. Also donate one Lone Pine seedling to every school in the district.

Erect a new memorial, dedicated to all those who served, outside the Karuah RSL & District Club. It will incorporate a free standing wing wall with the names of those who paid the ultimate sacrifice in all wars.
Upgrade the Northam World War I Honour Roll and attach it to the Northam War Memorial.
Establish a Memorial Park at Ballajura, Western Australia.

Purchase a commemorative wreath, constructed in four sections, made from lightweight material allowing easy transportation but making it strong and rigid enough to be bolted together for display purposes. Will be used at the 2005 Len Hall AFL game, and other commemorative activities in the future.
Restoration of two large WWII honour rolls at Auburn RSL Sub-branch consolidating it into one WWII honour roll.
Erect a flagpole at the Twin Towns Junior Centre to be used on days of commemoration.

Erect a new memorial wall in the existing Soldiers Memorial Park, Ettalong. Plaques will be placed on the memorial wall dedicated to ex-servicemen and women. A new wall is needed, as space is unavailable to continue this practice.

Preserve the Australian flag used by E Company, 27th Battalion during WW2. The flag will be enclosed in a display case. On completion the display case will be mounted on the wall in the memorial hall at the Swansea RSL Sub-Branch.
Refurbish the World War I Memorial located in South Perth.

To erect three bronze plaques dedicated to the memory of the four-crew members killed when their RAAF Lockheed Hudson bomber crashed into the side of Bong Bong Mountain, Dapto. Purchase a display cabinet to house memorabilia.
Update access to the Riverton SA memorial by providing a brick paved area with integrated cross.
Place two commemorative plaques to mark the site where two Japanese midget submarines were sunk in Sydney Harbour in 1942. One plaque will be placed at Taylors Bay and the other at George’s Head.
Hold a wreath laying ceremony and the dedication of a park bench with plaque attached, to commemorate the 60th anniversary of VP Day. To be followed by a light luncheon.

Relocate the Coburg Cenotaph to the Coburg RSL Gardens. The memorial needs to be moved as the Australian Legion Sub-branch in Brunswick where it was located closed down and the memorial was moved to local council offices.

Install an air-conditioner at the Sub-branch premises to encourage the continued use of the RSL Sub-branch premises as a venue for functions and social activities.
Purchase a public address system to assist hearing impaired veterans and war widows attending the social day club to participate in activities.
Assist in establishing a Men in Sheds facility in Bridgetown by purchasing woodworking equipment.
Purchase of PA system for use at functions and events.
Purchase of kitchen equipment for new RSL Sub-branch premises.
Assist in purchasing a laptop and printer for the Sub-branch to produce newsletters and to facilitate record keeping and distributing information to members.
Purchase a photocopier for the RSL Sub-branch newsletter.
Purchase PA system & furniture for the Lyrebird Day Care Club.
Install disabled toilet, open up hall for better useability, purchase of equipment for the Day Care Club.
Purchase a portable public address system for use both at its premises and for public events in Orbost.
Upgrade to Sub-branch kitchen to rejuvenate existing programs allowing for expansion and member recruitment.
Purchase carpets, tables, chairs and TV.
Provide recreational bus trips for Bellevue RSL members to overcome social isolation.
Purchase computer, printer and photocopier to support production of newsletter.
Preventing social isolation and health problems by providing weekly social activities and preventative health and welfare education.
Information night on Men’s Health Issues with presentations by specialist doctors and other health professionals.
Two Men’s Health nights (one in late 2004 & one in early 2005) to provide information on men’s health issues. Specialist doctors & other health professionals will give presentations.

Purchase a computer, printer and software to continue the production of their regular newsletter.
Assist with the cost of purchasing a 12-seater bus fitted with a hydraulic wheelchair lift and capacity for two wheelchairs, to be used for community transport.
Assist with the cost of upgrading its kitchen and toilet facilities. The improvements will provide accessible and safe facilities for all members.
Kitchen refurbishment to expand meals program, covered pergola to provide more area and a covered walkway to access the disabled toilet.

Purchase audio visual equipment to provide movie afternoons for veterans with hearing impairments.

Purchase a laptop computer and printer for the purpose of producing a local newsletter.
Healthy cooking classes delivered by final year university students in various locations in the Newcastle/Hunter region.

Improvement of facilities to continue and enhance a range of social and fitness activities.

Assist with costs associated with the dissemination of information on veterans issues to the ex-service community.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 14 September 2005:

item.para: What properties, or lettable floor areas at partially occupied properties, owned by the Commonwealth and in the possession of the department and each agency in the Minister’s portfolio, are currently not utilised by the department or agency in question, and are not let out.
For how long has each property, or part of a property, identified in part (1) been vacant and why has it been left vacant.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Mr Billson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Nil.
Not applicable.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Health and Ageing: Visit to Bali

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 10 October 2005:

item.para: When and by what means did he or his office or department learn of the intention of the Minister for Health and Ageing to take a family holiday in Bali, Indonesia, in September/October 2005.

Did the Minister for Health and Ageing seek advice from him, his office or department concerning the security situation in Indonesia prior to his holiday in Bali in September/October 2005; if so, what advice was given and when.
Did his department notify the Protective Security Coordination Centre in the Attorney-General’s Department of the Minister for Health and Ageing’s intention to holiday in Bali.
When was the Australian Consulate in Bali informed of the prospective visit to Bali of the Minister for Health and Ageing and his family.

Was the Minister for Health and Ageing’s decision to proceed with a family holiday in Bali consistent with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade’s public travel advice that Australians defer non-essential travel to Indonesia, including Bali.
Are Government Ministers and senior officials expected to set an example by heeding the travel advice issued by his department.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Mr Abbott discussed his travel plans with me (Mr Downer) before his trip. DFAT officers were not informed of the Minister for Health and Ageing’s intention to visit Bali with his family, as the Minister was travelling in a private capacity.
When Mr Abbott advised me (Mr Downer) that he was intending to travel to Bali for a holiday I advised him to consult the travel advice for Indonesia.
No. For any official travel the travelling Minister’s office would deal directly with the Protective Security Coordination Centre.

The Australian Consulate General in Bali was not informed of the prospective visit to Bali by the Minister for Health and Ageing and his family. The Consul General became aware of the Minister’s presence in Bali when the Minister initiated contact with the Consulate to offer his assistance to the victims of the bombing.
Decisions about travel can only be made by the individuals concerned.
The private travel of Government Ministers and senior officials is a private matter for them.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 11 October 2005:

item.para: For 2004-2005, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on domestic and international air travel.
For 2004-2005, what proportion of domestic air travel by employees of the Minister’s department was provided by (a) Qantas, (b) Regional Express, and (c) Virgin Blue.
For 2004-2005, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on domestic air travel provided by (i) Qantas, (ii) Regional Express, and (iii) Virgin Blue.
For 2004-2005, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on (a) economy and (b) business class travel on (i) domestic routes and (ii) international routes.

For 2004-2005, what proportion of the expenditure on air travel by the Minister’s department was on the domestic route (a) Sydney to Canberra, (b) Melbourne to Canberra, (c) Sydney to Melbourne, (d) Sydney to Brisbane, (e) Melbourne to Hobart or Launceston, and (f) Sydney to Perth.

For 2004-2005, how many employees of the Minister’s department had membership of the (a) Qantas Chairman’s Lounge, (b) Qantas Club, (c) Regional Express Membership Lounge, and (d) Virgin Blue’s Blue Room paid for by the department.
Which company provides travel management services to the Minister’s department.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Mr Billson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: $5,490,059 including Goods and Services Tax.
The following figures cover domestic air travel by both employees and veterans. These figures are not available separately for employees only.
Figures include Goods and Services Tax.
Figures include Goods and Services Tax.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: In addition there were domestic fares of $347,060 where no breakdown of economy/business class is available.

item.label: (b) (i)
item.para: Total international travel for all classes was $1,030,434, but no breakdown by economy/business class is available.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: See (i) above.
Figures below are percentages of the total expenditure on air travel for both domestic and international.
Qantas Business Travel.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, in writing, on 11 October 2005:

item.para: For 2004-2005, what sum was spent by the Minister’s department on domestic and international air travel.
For 2004-2005, what proportion of domestic air travel by employees of the Minister’s department was provided by (a) Qantas, (b) Regional Express, and (c) Virgin Blue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 13 October 2005:

item.para: Does the Minister’s department administer any Commonwealth funded programs to which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs.

Does the Minister’s department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs, and (b) were these paid advertisements, if so, what were the costs of each advertisement.
In respect of each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds.

In respect of each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses, and (c) individuals in the electoral division of Charlton received funding in (i) 2003, and (ii) 2004 and what was the name and address of each recipient.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Mr Billson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

Long Tan Bursary – The Bursary is administered by the Australian Veterans Children Assistance Trust (AVCAT) on behalf of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs (DVA). Thirty Bursaries are awarded each year across Australia. Each Bursary is valued at $6,000 and may be taken over one or two years.

Veteran & Community grants – DVA administers Veteran & Community (V&C) grants. To be eligible for a V&C grant, applicants must be an ex-service organisation, veteran representative group, community based organisation or private organisation that can demonstrate the ability to contribute to the welfare of members of the veteran community through the proposed project. Individuals are not eligible for funding under this program.

Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) grants program – for which ex-service organisations can apply for funding. Applications for 2006-07 BEST funding will be accepted in the 15 January – 28 February 2006 period.

Saluting Their Service Commemorations program – The aim of the program is to highlight the sacrifice and service of those who have served in wars, conflicts and peace operations in which Australia has been involved since Federation, and to promote appreciation and understanding of the role that those who served have played in shaping the nation.

Grants-in-Aid (GIA) program – The aim of the program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that these organisations provide to the ex-service community.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: and (b) The details of promoting the Long Tan Bursary, Veteran & Community Grants, BEST program, Saluting Their Service Commemoration programs and Grants-in-Aid (GIA) program are shown below.
targeted articles in ex-service organisation (ESO) and DVA publications;
DVA staff attending ESO and community network meetings;
dissemination of information to ex-service and targeted community organisations;
the Grantslink website, a government website that has a direct link to the V&C Grants site on DVAs website; and
DVA’s website. All details, including an application form, guidelines, contact details and an information sheet are available.
A booklet, Grants for Independence, that showcases projects funded by V&C Grants, was also widely distributed between 2002 and 2004.
(b) No.

(a) BEST is promoted on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs Internet website and the Department’s VetAffairs newsletter. BEST funding is also frequently publicised in Ex Service Organisation newsletters.
(b) No.
(a) The Australian Local Government Yearbook (published annually).
(b) Yes.
(a) Advertising of the GIA Program is limited to the Department’s website.
(b) No.

entry.para: Long Tan Bursary – The Bursary has been established to help eligible children of Vietnam veterans make the transition from secondary to tertiary education, so that they can work towards the formal qualifications and skills needed to pursue their chosen career. Each year Bursaries are awarded to successful applicants from each State and Territory.

AVCAT through a competitive selection process provide a short list of recommended applicants to the Repatriation Commission in late February of each year. The Repatriation Commission then considers each applicant and makes a decision.

V&C Grants – V&C Grants provide funds for projects that support a healthy, quality lifestyle for members of the veteran community and assist them to remain living independently in their own homes. The wider community can also participate in and benefit from projects.
The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs is responsible for approving the allocation of funds on the recommendations of the Department.
The aim of the BEST program is to provide support and resources to ESO practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist the veteran and service community.
The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs is responsible for approving the allocation of funds on the recommendations of the Department.

Saluting Their Service provides funding towards the restoration, preservation, upgrading and construction of community war memorials; the restoration, preservation and interpretation of Australian wartime memorabilia for public display; commemoration of significant wartime anniversaries; unit wartime histories, where none exists; school initiatives such as projects involving local veterans; and significant unit reunions.
The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs is responsible for approving applications for grants after considering recommendations of the Commemorations Grants Advisory Committee.
The aim of the GIA program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that these organisations provide to the ex-service community.
The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs is responsible for approving the allocation of funds on the recommendations of the Department.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 31 October 2005:

item.para: What sum was spent by the Commonwealth Government on (a) travel, (b) accommodation, and (c) other expenses (including meals and incidentals) as a consequence of the State visit to China in October 2005 by Their Excellencies the Governor-General and Mrs Jeffery.
What are the details of the accommodation used by the Governor‑General and Mrs Jeffery on this journey.
Who accompanied Their Excellencies on this journey.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Official Secretary to the Governor-General has provided the following information:

item.para: Official Secretary, Aide-de-Camp to the Governor-General, DFAT Officer, doctor, interpreter, personal staff (1), Federal Agents.
1 Air travel Canberra-Sydney-Canberra was undertaken using VIP aircraft paid by the Department of Defence.
2 Meal costs are included with accommodation costs.
3 The costs include only expenses of Their Excellencies, Official Secretary and other Government House staff, interpreter, DFAT Officer and doctor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 7 November 2005:

item.para: Does the Government accept that it withdrew from Afghanistan prematurely in 2002 and left the job unfinished.
Has Australia’s deployment to Iraq prevented, constrained or delayed the ADF’s ability to deploy a Provisional Reconstruction Team (PRT) to Afghanistan.
When does the Government expect to deploy a PRT and what will be the duration of its deployment.
Has the failure to upgrade the Army’s fleet of M113 Armoured Personnel Carriers impeded the ADF’s ability to deploy a PRT or potentially deploy mechanised infantry to Afghanistan.
What has been the effect on Australia’s Special Forces units of their high rate of deployment/rotation.
Is the number of Special Forces troops leaving the army for the private sector particularly high; if so, what measures is the ADF taking to reduce it.
Are Australian Special Forces troops experiencing disproportionately high rates of divorce/family breakdown.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: No.
No.
The Government expects the Australian contribution to a Dutch-led Provincial Reconstruction Team to deploy later this year for a period of up to two years.
No.

The current rate of operational deployments has had no negative effect on Australia’s Special Forces units. Australia’s Special Forces units have been able to maintain all of their operational, contingency planning and training requirements.
The Australian Defence Force (ADF) does not maintain records that identify if Special Forces personnel are leaving the Army for positions in the private sector.
Defence social workers have not noticed a higher incidence of marital breakdowns among Special Forces personnel who have sought counselling assistance when compared to the wider ADF population.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 28 November 2005:

item.para: Did the Minister’s department engage:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Excelerated Consulting at a cost of $49,500;

item.label: (b)
item.para: PSI Consulting at a cost of $40,656; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: Dale Roger Louis Boucher at a cost of $330,600; if so, in respect of each consultancy, why was it considered necessary and what work was carried out under its terms.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Excelerated Consulting were engaged to customize existing software to collect cross agency information through a dedicated website. The collection related to Australian Government Indigenous Specific programs, investment and expenditure. The exercise is a first step in collecting data to enable reporting on whole-of-government Indigenous investment at the service delivery level.
The customisation took place in October for data collection in November. The expertise was not available internally.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Yes. PSI Consulting Pty Ltd were engaged from the DIMIA Panel of Procurement Advisory Service to provide specialist support and expert advice to the Office of Indigenous Policy Coordination (OIPC) in relation to the procurement for a Multi-use List (MUL) of Community Facilitators/Coordinators. Independent expertise was not available in-house.

The MUL process is not yet completed. The services provided by PSI to date include: the development of the MUL documentation, probity advice in regard to the procurement process and technical support for the assessment team.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Mr Boucher has been engaged as an independent consultant to investigate allegations of misconduct arising from the recommendations of the Comrie Inquiry Report. The estimated cost of his contract is $330,600. The actual cost will depend on how much work is needed to complete the investigation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 1 December 2005:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1930 (Hansard, 28 November 2005, page 108), can the Minister provide the same information in respect of the financial year ending 30 June (a) 2000, (b) 2001, (c) 2002, (d) 2003, and (e) 2004.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Note: For all tables, figures in brackets show number of complaints substantiated by 20 December 2005.
The overall figures for the 225 complaints reported for the period are:
163 (72%) - substantiated;
28 (12%) - unsubstantiated (insufficient evidence to prove or disprove);
13 (6%) - withdrawn by complainant;
6 (3%) - not able to be resolved prior to respondent/s’ discharge/employment termination; and
15 (7%) - pending/not able to be finalised due to time elapsed.
The overall figures for the 271 complaints reported for the period are:
167 (62%) - substantiated;
63 (23%) - unsubstantiated (insufficient evidence to prove or disprove);
17 (6%) - withdrawn by complainant;
11 (4%) - not able to be resolved prior to respondent/s’ discharge/employment termination; and
13 (5%) - pending/not able to be finalised due to time elapsed.
The overall figures for the 326 complaints reported for the period are:
229 (70%) - substantiated;
55 (17%) - unsubstantiated (insufficient evidence to prove or disprove);
23 (7%) - withdrawn by complainant;
15 (5%) - not able to be resolved prior to respondent/s’ discharge/employment termination; and
4 (1%) - pending/not able to be finalised due to time elapsed.
The overall figures for the 440 complaints reported for the period are:
298 (68%) - substantiated;
89 (20%) - unsubstantiated (insufficient evidence to prove or disprove);
19 (4%) - withdrawn by complainant;
22 (5%) - not able to be resolved prior to respondent/s’ discharge/employment termination; and
12 (3%) - pending finalisation.
The overall figures for the 587 complaints reported for the period are:
379 (65%) - substantiated;
86 (15%) - unsubstantiated (insufficient evidence to prove or disprove);
37 (6%) - withdrawn by complainant;
37 (6%) - not able to be resolved prior to respondent/s’ discharge/employment termination; and
48 (8%) - pending finalisation.

When respondents are discharged or have their employment terminated, Defence has no further jurisdiction and cannot pursue complaints any further. When a complainant leaves Defence prior to the finalisation of a complaint, the process can continue if the respondent is still a Defence member. There is a higher proportion of sexual offences that have not been substantiated than for other categories. This is mainly because they are criminal offences for which, in many cases, the civilian police have found insufficient evidence to prosecute.
The honourable member should note that reasons for the increased reporting include:

item.para: increased awareness of what constitutes unacceptable behaviour;
mandatory training in 2003-04 and 2004-05 emphasised the processes for making and managing complaints;
greater confidence that issues will be addressed by management;
Services have increased efforts to encourage units to submit reports; and
increased culture of reporting in the Australian Defence Force.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, in writing, on 1 December 2005:

item.para: What sum did the Government pay for the design and construction of the Australian War Memorial in Hyde Park, London.
Does the Government pay for, or contribute, the upkeep of the memorial; if so, what sum was spent on its upkeep in 2004-2005.
Is it the case that the memorial recognises only one Australian Prime Minister; if so, why; if not, will she list each of the Australian wartime leaders recognised by the memorial.

What assessment criteria did the Office of Australian War Graves use to determine which Australian wartime leaders would appear on the memorial and did she, or her office, have any involvement in the development of the assessment criteria.

talker.name: Billson, Bruce, MP
talker.role: Minister for Veterans’ Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence
talker.name: Mr Billson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The memorial was fully maintained under warranty for 12 months from November 2003. From November 2004 to June 2005 $19 000 was expended.

The Memorial does not specifically recognise any Prime Ministers. It comprises a long curving wall set with 24,000 place names recording the home towns of Australian men and women who served during the two world wars. Superimposed on these place names are 47 battle sites, representing theatres of war where Australians served. It also features the three Service insignia – Navy, Army and Air Force – and the Australian Commonwealth Coat of Arm as well as the quotation “Whatever burden you are to carry, we also will shoulder that burden” by the wartime Prime Minister Robert Menzies is inscribed on the Memorial. ’

The OAWG sought a quote that encapsulated the Memorial’s aim: to commemorate those Australians who served alongside Britons in the two world wars. The quotation “Whatever burden you are to carry, we also will shoulder that burden” by Prime Minister Menzies was determined to be the most suitable. The Memorial was completed before the Hon De-Anne Kelly MP was appointed Minister for Veterans’ Affairs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 6 December 2005:

item.para: When will the current contract for the provision of tertiary legal education services for military legal officers expire.
Has the request for tender process for a provider of tertiary legal education services for military legal officers commenced; if so, when.
When is the tender process expected to conclude.
Can the Minister confirm that a new contract for the provision of tertiary legal education services for military legal officers will be in place before the expiration of the current contract.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The previous contract for the provision of tertiary legal education services for Australian Defence Force (ADF) Legal Officers between the Commonwealth and the University of Melbourne expired on 31 December 2005.

The request for tender for the provision of legal education services was issued on 30 April 2005 with an original deadline for tender submission of 30 May 2005. Following receipt of written requests for deadline extension from two prospective tenderers (one of which was the then contract holder - The University of Melbourne), the deadline was extended to 1 August 2005.
The tender process has concluded.

A contract for the provision of tertiary legal education services for ADF Legal Officers between the Commonwealth and The Australian National University was executed on 13 January 2006. The short break in contract continuity over the Christmas period has not affected the provision of tertiary legal services to ADF officers. The Australian National University is scheduled to offer the first of the core military legal education subjects in May 2006. In accordance with the transition arrangements negotiated by Defence, some students will continue to undertake the study of elective subjects at the University of Melbourne throughout 2006.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 7 December 2005:

item.para: Can the Minister confirm that no Memoranda of Understanding currently exist between the State/Territory Coroners and the Department of Defence in respect of the post-mortem handling of members of the ADF who die whilst in service.

Can the Minister confirm that a draft Memorandum of Understanding was prepared by Victoria Police in conjunction with the State Coroner of Victoria but that this draft document was never signed off by the ADF.

Does the lack of a concise statement detailing the roles and responsibilities of the ADF and the State/Territory Coroners in respect of the post-mortem handling of members of the ADF who die whilst in service place undue pressure on ADF commanders in terms of their responsibilities in the handling of deceased members; if not, can the Minister explain why not.

Can the Minister confirm that the respective Defence Instructions pertaining to the post-mortem handling of members of the ADF who die whilst in service (a) does not adequately state the roles and responsibilities of the ADF and the State/Territory Coroners in those circumstances and (b) does not carry the legislative authority to demand compliance with the guidelines contained therein.

Can the Minister confirm that the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee inquiry into the effectiveness of Australia’s military justice system confirmed that State and Territory Coroners retain the primary responsibility to investigate deaths in the ADF.
Can the Minister confirm that the primacy of the State or Territory Coroners in respect of the investigation of deaths in the ADF is not currently widely promulgated throughout the ADF.

Will Memoranda of Understanding clarify the position and provide for wide promulgation of the primacy of State or Territory Coroners in respect of the investigation of deaths in the ADF; if not, can the Minister explain why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. However, Defence and the Coroners have been engaged in extensive consultations and it is anticipated that appropriate arrangements will be finalised in 2006.
No, Defence is not aware of such a document.

No. Within Defence, Defence Instruction (General) Personnel 20-6 “Deaths within and outside Australia of Australian Defence personnel” and Australian Defence Force (ADF) Publication 202 “Administrative Inquiries Manual” provide information and advice on the management of these matters. Further, the roles and responsibilities of the ADF and the State/Territory coroners have been the subject of ongoing discussions and exercises.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Administrative Inquiries Manual and the Defence Instruction must be read with the applicable Defence legislation, including a Ministerial direction issued by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence on 5 May 2004. Together, these documents set out the roles and responsibilities of the ADF and State/Territory Coroners where a member of the ADF dies while in service. The Defence Instruction will be reviewed, with some minor amendments expected, to improve consistency with the Ministerial Direction.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Defence Instructions are general orders for the purposes of section 29 of the Defence Force Discipline Act (1988). Members of the ADF may be subject to disciplinary action under the Act for a failure to comply with any mandatory terms.
Yes.
and (7) The policy is contained in the Defence Instruction (General) Personnel and the Administrative Inquiries Manual, which apply to, and are readily accessible by, all members of the ADF.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 8 December 2005:

item.para: Since 2003-2004, what sum has the Minister’s department spent on services provided by law firms on matters associated with outsourcing information technology services.
Which law firms have been responsible for providing these services.
Which partners or principals of those firms have been responsible for undertaking or supervising those services.
